Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] use System.Reflection.Metadata in <ResolveAssemblies/>" (#2612) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context: https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/tree/master/src/System.Reflection.Metadata/src/System/Reflection/Metadata
Context: https://github.com/jonathanpeppers/Benchmarks

There is a new System.Reflection.Metadata library from corefx for
reading .NET assemblies. It is a bit more performant than Mono.Cecil
because it is a different library with different opinions.

Some notes about System.Reflection.Metadata:

- SRM has a forward "reader" style API
- SRM uses lots of structs, and you have to do an additional call to
lookup strings generally.
- SRM, as far as I have seen, doesn't have APIs to modify and write
out new assemblies.
- SRM only supports "portable" pdb files.
- SRM is not well documented yet. To discover usage, I read source
  code and/or unit tests.

From my benchmark above, it seems that SRM is 10x faster on
Windows/.NET framework and 5x faster on macOS/Mono.

So it makes sense for use to use SRM when reading assemblies (and we
don't need symbols), and continue with Mono.Cecil for the linker and
other things that modify assemblies.

There are a few places we can take advantage of SRM, but the simplest
with a reasonable impact was `ResolveAssemblies`:

    Before:
    320 ms  ResolveAssemblies                          1 calls
    After:
    112 ms  ResolveAssemblies                          1 calls

So a ~200ms savings on this MSBuild task, which runs on *every* build.
This was the Xamarin.Forms test project in this repo: a build with no
changes.

## Changes ##

- Added a `MetadataResolver` type, as a way to cache `PEReader`
  instances. This is a comparable drop-in replacement for
  `DirectoryAssemblyResolver`.
- `MonoAndroidHelper.IsReferenceAssembly` now uses
  `System.Reflection.Metadata` instead of `Mono.Cecil`. This is used
  in a few other MSBuild tasks.
- A `MetadataExtensions` provides an extension method to simplify
  getting the full name of a custom attribute. We can add more here as
  needed.

The resulting code *should* be the same, except we are using SRM over
Mono.Cecil.

## Downstream ##

We will need to add the following assemblies to the installer:

- `System.Reflection.Metadata.dll`
- `System.Collections.Immutable.dll`

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Shell] Cannot navigate to a relative URI" (#4971) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description

I should be able to navigate to a page without knowing the entire URI by using a relative URI. When doing this it does nothing:

```
Shell.CurrentShell.GoToAsync("/photo?payload=4.0", true);
```

or

```
Shell.CurrentShell.GoToAsync("photo?payload=4.0", true);
```

This crashes:

```
Shell.CurrentShell.GoToAsync(new ShellNavigationState(new Uri("photo?payload=4.0", UriKind.Absolute)));
```

"photo" is a route name in my Shell.xaml.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 4.0-pre2

### Reproduction Link

https://github.com/davidortinau/Gastropods

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Shell] Route navigation doesn't seem to work" (#4970) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description

I'm trying to register a route and navigate to it, but it doesn't work.

Register the route in the Shell.xaml.cs:
```
Routing.RegisterRoute("takephoto", typeof(CameraPage));
```

Then navigate to that named route:
```
Shell.CurrentShell.GoToAsync("app:///gastropod/a/b/takephoto?payload=4.0", true);
```

This just returns  me to the home page. I can use other paths  before the "takephoto" route and it'll  put me on those pages, but never takes me to the `CameraPage` as desired.

I **can** navigate  to a route named in the Shell.xaml like this:

```
<ShellItem Route="toptabs" Title="Top Tabs" FlyoutIcon="iconXamarin.png" Style="{StaticResource QuaternaryShell}">
        <ShellSection Route="activity" Title="Activity" Icon="iconXamarin.png" >
            <ShellContent Route="shared" Title="Shared" ContentTemplate="{DataTemplate local:ActivityPage}" />
            <ShellContent Route="notifications" Title="Notifications" ContentTemplate="{DataTemplate local:NotificationsPage}" />
            <ShellContent Route="photo" Title="Photo" ContentTemplate="{DataTemplate local:CameraPage}" />
        </ShellSection>
    </ShellItem>
```

And then:

```
Shell.CurrentShell.GoToAsync("app:///gastropod/toptabs/activity/photo?payload=4.0", true);
```

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 4.0-pre2

### Reproduction Link

Based on https://github.com/davidortinau/Gastropods

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "BoxView.BackgroundColor binding does not work on WPF" (#4959) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description of Change ###
As was mentioned, that BoxView works fine with **Color** but doesn't with **BackgroundColor**
Set the same renderer's handler for both properties.

### Issues Resolved ### 
- fixes #4788 

### API Changes ###
None

### Platforms Affected ### 
- WPF

### Behavioral/Visual Changes ###
Can update BackgroundColor with bindings

### Before/After Screenshots ### 
Not applicable

### Testing Procedure ###

Try to bind BackgroundColor of BoxView to VM's property

```xml
<BoxView
    BackgroundColor="{Binding Color}"
    HeightRequest="100"
    WidthRequest="100" />
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "BoxView.BackgroundColor binding does not work on WPF" (#4788) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
`BoxView.BackgroundColor` does not update when bound to a `Xamarin.Forms.Color` ViewModel property on WPF. It *does* use the inital value of the property to set its background color, but does not react to changes of the property.

Related issue: #4338 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download and open repro
2. Start the WPF application
3. Click the "Switch" button

### Expected Behavior
The `BoxView`'s color should change.

### Actual Behavior
The `BoxView`'s color does not change.

### Additional Info
The `BoxView.Color` property works as expected and could be considered a valid workaround as I did not yet come across a situation where `BoxView.Color` behaves differently than `BoxView.BackgroundColor`. In `MainPage.xaml`, there's a commented-out `BoxView` that binds the color to `BoxView.Color`, which works as expected.

```xaml
<!--  this works  -->
<!--<BoxView
    HeightRequest="100"
    WidthRequest="100"
    Color="{Binding Color}" />-->
<!--  this does not  -->
<BoxView
    BackgroundColor="{Binding Color}"
    HeightRequest="100"
    WidthRequest="100" />
```

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: Latest stable (3.4.0.1008975) and latest prerelease (4.0.0.8055-pre1)
- IDE: Visual Studio 15.9.4
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - WPF: .NET Framework 4.7.1
- Nuget Packages: None

### Reproduction Link

<!-- Please upload or provide a link to a reproduction case -->
[BgBoxViewBindingIssue.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/2690293/BgBoxViewBindingIssue.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "AVCaptureSession not working on Xam.Mac" (#5390) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- 🚨 STOP 🚨 𝗦𝗧𝗢𝗣 🚨 𝑺𝑻𝑶𝑷 🚨 -->

<!--
Please fill in the *entire* template below.
The template is designed to avoid unnecessary delays to confirm and fix reported issues. Issues with missing information generally end up with a `need-info` label and take significantly more time to fix. Please help us help you!
For more information see https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-&-Suggestions
For support requests use https://www.xamarin.com/support
-->
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Build and run attached test project on MacOS "avcapturesessiontest" on a computer that has a video source like a USB webcam or iSight cam.
2. The ViewController class then
2b. Asks permission to access camera and microphone for input.
2c. Creates and AVCaptureSession object
2d. Finds default video input and creates input device object
2e. Adds input device to AVCaptureSession
2f. Adds output for live preview to AVCaptureSession with sample buffer output delegate
2g. Creates AV PreviewLayer from AVCaptureSession
2h. Adds live preview layer as layer or sublayer of ViewController's NSView object.
2g. AVCaptureSession.StartRunning is called.
3. Nothing displays in preview layer, and no sample buffers are output even though current state of AVCaptureSession.Running is true.

### Expected Behavior
Upon application launch, live camera/video input should be displayed in View of ViewController.
Sample Buffer should be ouput to delegate with every frame of video input.

### Actual Behavior
Nothing displays in preview layer, and no sample buffers are output even though current state of AVCaptureSession.Running is true.

### Environment

Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce


1. pull down Xamarin Forms repro with the iOS-create branch
   https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/tree/ios-recreate

2. run build.sh (this will open VS)
3. set Xamarin.Forms.ControlGallery.iOS to startup project
4. click "go to test cases"
5. now in the search bar type and delete things. If it doesn't crash then try clicking one of the bugs in the list then go back and typing again

### Actual Behavior

Events.RelatedBody:

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Build a Xamarin project with both EF Core 2.2 (which requires .NET Core 2.2)
2. Create a data model and a DB Context.
3. Get it running on Android.
4. Try to deploy the app to an iPhone and access data using EF.

Everything works fine.

### Actual Behavior
It fails.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[msbuild/tests] Ensure our FrameworkList files have correct assemblies" (#5367) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
One mono bump (https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/commit/6f2ebedb74fe8da250c8f53b61ffae2eb86fc711#diff-e801bb766cbaad95b50b1487b865f971) changed our `Xamarin.iOS-FrameworkList.xml.in` (and the tvOS and watchOS ones) and added 2 files

```
<File AssemblyName="System.Buffers" Version="4.0.99.0" />
<File AssemblyName="System.Memory" Version="4.0.99.0" />
```

Around the same time this change was made in the IDE: https://github.com/mono/monodevelop/blob/e355f65870da4847d77ed1f3f2d07d1f78889cec/main/src/core/MonoDevelop.Core/MonoDevelop.Core.Assemblies/TargetFramework.cs#L260
That means that VSMac, when creating a new cache file listing the assemblies, won’t scan the assemblies in those directories `/Library/Frameworks/Xamarin.iOS.framework/Versions/Current/lib/mono/Xamarin.iOS`.
This resulted in an incomplete cache file missing most assemblies leading to the IDE showing red checkmarks for known and installed assemblies.

Ideally the FrameworkList files we ship should have a list of all the assemblies with PublicKeyToken and friends (the framework shouldn't be lazy and expect the IDEs to generate that file for us).

This commit ships a test using the same logic as the IDE to populate the FrameworkList file. The test will report any missing assembly and print the xml element that should be added to the file.
E.g: `<File AssemblyName="FSharp.Core" Version="3.98.4.0" PublicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" ProcessorArchitecture="MSIL" />`
Then it's only a matter of copy/pasting that (:

Note: even though this is the msbuild tests for iOS land I'm also scanning the Xamarin.Mac files here for simplicity.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[XHarness] Reenable the System.ServiceModel tests from the bcl." (#5384) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Failing tests are because:

1. Files are missing for the tests.
2. We yet do not have tests for the watch platform, we execute the iOS ones and ignore those that are not supported in the platform.
